text: this is the entrance to the fam lion
cave this is where all the activity is
focused and things are winding down here
now for the night because the operation
will take a pause as it did last night
they will have a rest they'll rebuild
their energy and they'll resupply the
equipment that they need to finish off
this job to continue the mission
tomorrow to rescue the remaining four
boys and their coach but today has been
really positive there's been so much
more good news the fact that they've
been able to bring out another four boys
to join the four who were taken to a
hospital yesterday and we're just
getting some lines through from a press
conference that's being held by the
officials in charge of the operation
that they've thanked the royal family
for supporting this operation they say
that it started at around 11 o'clock
here this morning and by 8:00 p.m. this
evening all the boys were sent to the
local hospital and they say they are
well they said the operation today
lasted nine hours that's two hours
quicker than the operation yesterday so
it shows you that they're getting more
familiar with the routine they're
getting to know the way that they're
actually getting these boys out and
they're able to actually do it quicker
than they were yesterday so everything
here has been positive today much more
good news I'll tell you a bit more about
exactly how this rescue is being
conducted but I'll just bring you this
detail that we're getting from the
official press conference they've had
more officers working today and say they
are more experienced but there were 18
divers at the core of this rescue that's
the same as yesterday and we know that
that's a team of 13 internationally
renowned cave divers who have come here
to Thailand from right around the world
to bring their expertise from diving in
some of the toughest parts of the world
it's that experience that skill that has
come up with this rescue plan and is now
putting it into action so successfully
and those 13 international divers are
joined by five from the Royal Thai Navy
the best five divers that they could
pick but there is a huge support team
here and that's what you've seen just
coming in and out of the cave complex
really some of the volunteers most of
them who are supporting this rescue
effort the military and the police also
involved in huge
so lots of people moving back and
forward lots of logistics that have to
be put in place to keep this rescue plan
on track and there will be people here
overnight even though the rescue attempt
is being paused they'll still be
monitoring conditions in the cave and
making sure that everything's ready for
tomorrow morning when they'll return to
go in again and try and bring out those
remaining four boys and their coach and
we know that the prime minister also
paid a visit here today the Prime
Minister of Thailand and he's visited
some of the parents who are at the
hospital which is an hour's drive from
here in a town called chiang rai the
ambulances that have brought the boys
out have been heading off in that
direction to drive them to hospital or
in that direction to reach a helicopter
landing pad which is being created at
the bottom of the road here where
there's some flat land and some of the
boys have been flown to the helicopter
so the Prime Minister has visited there
today and spoken with some of their
parents and we know the four boys who
were rescued yesterday are still being
treated in hospital they've actually
been held in quarantine officials said
because they want to monitor them they
want to check exactly what their health
is because they've spent more than two
weeks deep in that cave and they don't
quite know exactly what they've been
subjected to exactly what issues they
may have so they're taking their time
they're being very careful not just in
bringing the boys out to the surface but
then in making sure they get the care
they need in hospital and there's no
doubt for anyone that they will need
more time to get over this ordeal to
come to terms with exactly what's
happened and to readjust to life outside
and they're already the focus of a lot
of media attention the eyes of the world
have been on this rescue attempt ever
since it started two weeks ago and these
boys will now be to some degree famous
they've been through such a big ordeal
and such a daring rescue that looks like
so far it's going successful now let me
talk about the way this rescuers
unfolded since the boys first went
missing more than two weeks ago they
went into that cave down that road and
in that cave with their football coach a
25 year old we believe it was one of the
boys birthdays and there's a local
tradition here where on your birthday
you
at the cave and write your name on the
wall we understand that's what the boys
were doing when they found suddenly it
was raining heavily outside the cave and
the water level inside started
increasing that forced them deeper into
the cave trying to escape the rising
water that is how they got trapped and
for ten days no one knew where they were
or whether they were alive
it took divers that amount of time to
explore in the flooded caverns and
passages that make up this cave complex
before they discovered the boys stranded
sitting above the water on a dry ledge
but everyone's concerned then was that
the water level could rise further and
put them at risk it rains really heavily
here especially at the moment it's
monsoon season so there's been a race
against time to beat any heavy rain and
although it has rained over the last few
days the water level in the cave has
been relatively stable they've been
pumping water furiously ever since the
boys went missing millions of liters of
water pumped out of the cave to try and
stop the water level increasing now then
they had to explore options for actually
getting the boys out an impossible
puzzle a really tricky conundrum there's
the option of waiting for the water
level to drop so that they could walk
out the way that they went in but that
could have taken months there's the
option of drilling down from above to
try and free them from above but the
terrain here is really hilly really
steep cliffs that are covered in thick
jungle vegetation so officials were
finding it difficult to even work out
where they needed to start drilling to
dig down the 600 metres or so it would
have taken to reach that cavern
they'd have been exploring different
bore holes they've been trying that but
they favored this method of teaching the
boys to scuba dive so that they could
effectively be swum out under the water
that's what's been going on for the last
few days the caving expert teaching them
how to swim in the first place some of
them because they've not been in the
water before and then trying to make
them familiar with the techniques of
scuba diving giving them a mask
to put over their faces with air supply
that will help them breathe and making
them comfortable
with the equipment with the sensation of
being underwater it may be cold it may
be dark it's difficult to navigate you
don't know what obstacles are coming up
and some of the narrow passageways that
they've had to wriggle through to get
themselves free mean that this is one of
the most challenging cave dives in the
world even many experienced cave divers
would struggle getting through some of
these bottlenecks and we know that one
of the dive rescue team lost his life
here a former tide a Navy diver who was
working at Bangkok Airport and
volunteered to come back he was leaving
the cave after taking some air supply
tanks in when he lost consciousness and
lost his life a 38 year old called
salmon Coonan now he's been held up as a
hero for the sacrifice he made as part
of this rescue attempt but that made
everyone more determined to make sure
that there was a successful outcome
so having spent that time teaching the
boys the techniques that they would need
to get free yesterday the plan was put
into action
d-day they called it an opportunity in
the weather and their confidence in the
boys ability that's why they started
leading a small group out expert divers
guiding each boy through that difficult
narrow passageways there are parts where
they emerge from the water and have to
take the equipment off and walk for a
bit but then it's submerged again and
they have to dive once more and even
when they reached the dry part of the
cave they're still almost the miles walk
away from the entrance so this has been
a really tough journey to the surface
but one that has gone successfully so
far for eight of these boys but for more
still stuck in that cave tonight along
with the 25 year old coach and they will
have to spend a 17th night in there who
knows how they sleep in there who knows
what dark nightmares they've had in
those 17 nights this ordeal has gone on
and on but it looks like rescue is now
closed successful rescue for eight of
these boys and everyone here hoping that
that success can be repeated tomorrow so
that there is a happy conclusion for
everyone involved in this story it would
be an amazing feat of human endeavor
countering all the challenges that
nature has laid down for them here but
people really have come together have
worked together have applied
their skills their experience in a
tremendous effort to solve this puzzle
to free those boys and to save those 13
lives
